Group 1.abound: exist in large numbers or amounts

Group 31.serendipitous: happening or done by chance in a happy or useful way
shirk: avoid or neglect (a duty or responsibility)
malinger or pretend to be ill in order to avoid work or duty
Group 31.sinecure: a position or office that requires little or no work, especially one that provides an income
sinuous: winding or turning in a snake-like fashion
stanch: stop the flow of a liquid
to stop or check something, especially bleeding
surfeit: excessive indulgence in food or drink
Group 31.ulterior: beyond what is openly admitted or expressed; hidden
voluble: given to fluent or incessant talk

abstruse: difficult to understand; obscure or esoteric
hard to understand; ambiguous or vague
caricature: a picture or drawing that exaggerates a person's features for comic effect
a distortion or exaggeration of something
dilettante: a person who cultivates an area of interest, such as the arts, without real commitment or knowledge
a dabbler in a field or activity
encroach: to enter and occupy a place or area that does not belong to you
to take something, especially gradually or stealthily, that does not belong to you
Group 32.endow: to give someone or something a quality or ability
entreat: to ask someone in a very polite and urgent way to do something
to make a request to someone in a respectful and sincere manner
Group 32.indictment: a formal statement that charges a person with a crime
Group 32.indignant: feeling or showing anger or annoyance at something that is unfair or unjust
inquisitive: having a curiosity that prompts one to investigate and learn
Group 32.latitude: Angular distance north or south of the equator
levity: a feeling of lightheartedness and freedom from serious concerns
a lack of seriousness or solemnity
a disposition to jest or trifle
Group 32.malevolent: having or showing a wish to do harm to someone
mediate: to settle or resolve disputes or differences between two or more parties
to act as an intermediary or a go-between in a dispute or negotiation
to have an effect or influence on something or someone
occlude: to stop something from being seen or to block the view of it
to block or close a passage or an opening
to prevent something such as a tooth from functioning properly
pacify: to make someone or something calm or peaceful
to placate or appease someone by giving them what they want
Group 32.paragon: a model of excellence or perfection
patronize: to treat in a condescending manner, as if giving charity
to act as a patron to; support or sponsor
piquant: Having a pleasantly sharp or appetizing flavor
Having a biting or attractive quality
remote: controlled or operated from a distance
reprobate: a person who is considered to be worthless or of bad character
a person who is rejected by God or is considered to be evil
Group 32.turbid: cloudy or thick with suspended particles, making it difficult to see through
turgid: swollen or distended, especially due to fluid or gas
bombastic or overly elaborate in language or style

affluent: having a great deal of money; wealthy
allegorical: symbolic; representing abstract ideas through symbolic figures
allude: to suggest or call attention to indirectly; hint at
to refer to something casually or indirectly
amplify: to make larger or more powerful; enlarge
to increase the volume of sound
to add detail or expand upon something
catastrophic: involving or causing sudden great damage or suffering
contemporary: living or occurring at the same time
a person or thing living or existing at the same time as another
conundrum: a confusing and difficult problem or question
a riddle, especially one with a pun in its answer
a dilemma with no clear solution
defame: to damage the good reputation of someone; slander or libel
to make wrongful statements about someone to harm their reputation
detract: to reduce the value or importance of something
to divert attention away from something
to take away from the quality or reputation of something
devious: showing a skillful use of underhanded tactics to achieve goals
dormant: not active but capable of becoming active
in a state of rest or suspension
draconian: rigidly severe in rules or punishment
egalitarian: believing in or based on the principle that all people are equal and deserve equal rights and opportunities
relating to the equality of all people
elusive: difficult to find, catch, or achieve
erstwhile: previously holding a particular role or status
gloat: to dwell on one's own success or another's misfortune with smugness or malignant pleasure
to show excessive satisfaction or pride
to boast about one's achievements in a spiteful way
indefinite: having no clear limits or end
keen: having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm
sober: not affected by alcohol; abstaining from alcohol
serious, sensible, and solemn in demeanor
stem from: to originate in or be caused by something
to arise from a particular source
subdued: quiet and rather reflective or depressed
soft and restrained in style or color
token: a thing serving as a visible or tangible representation or symbol
something done or given as a symbolic gesture rather than for practical reasons
unravel: to investigate and solve or explain something complicated or puzzling
to undo or untangle something that is knotted or woven
withstand: to remain undamaged or unaffected by; resist
to endure or hold up against

artful: clever or skillful, especially in a cunning way
avid: having or showing a keen interest in something
brevity: concise and exact use of words
bromide: a trite or unoriginal idea or remark
circumstantial: dependent on or conditioned by circumstances
based on particular circumstances rather than general principles
cloying: overly sweet or sentimental to the point of disgust
counterfeit: made in exact imitation to deceive
disciple: a follower or student of a teacher, leader, or philosophy
someone who adheres to the teachings of a particular person
forebode: to predict or warn of something bad
ideologue: a person who strongly supports a set of ideas
someone who adheres strictly to a particular ideology
a follower of a specific doctrine or theory
impediment: something that delays or prevents progress
impulsive: acting on instinct rather than deliberation
intuitive: based on what one feels to be true without conscious reasoning
lassitude: a state of physical or mental weariness
omit: to neglect to mention or do
paltry: meager; small in amount or size
prefigure: to represent or symbolize something in advance
presage: be a sign or warning of something, especially something bad
prescribe: authorize or recommend the use of medicine or treatment
to set down as a rule or guideline
propitiate: win or regain the favor of by doing something that pleases
recapitulate: summarize and state again the main points
